etymologies: mid 19th century: from French répertoire, from late Latin repertorium (see repertory)

definitions: a stock of plays, dances, or pieces that a company or a performer knows or is prepared to perform.
shortDefinitions: stock of plays, dances, or items that company or performer knows or is prepared to perform

definitions: the whole body of items which are regularly performed
shortDefinitions: whole body of items which are regularly performed

definitions: a stock of skills or types of behavior that a person habitually uses

examples.text: his repertoire of threats, stares, and denigratory gestures

shortDefinitions: stock of skills or types of behaviour that person habitually uses
